abstract.text: Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: SceneKit provides two ways to integrate custom GPU shader programs into the rendering of your scene: program objects and shader modifiers.

content.text: Use Program Objects to Replace SceneKit Shading

inlineContent.text: For complete control of the vertex and fragment shaders used to render an object, assign an

instance to the object’s program property. A custom program completely replaces all other rendering parameters, including material settings. Your custom program takes inputs from SceneKit and is responsible for all transform, lighting, and shading effects you want it to produce. For details on custom programs, see

When you specify a custom program, you can provide handler blocks that SceneKit calls at render time to update the values of custom variables in your shaders. See the methods in Handling Parameters in Custom OpenGL Shader Programs.

content.text: Use Shader Modifiers to Extend SceneKit Shading

inlineContent.text: Shader modifiers are an alternative to entirely replacing SceneKit’s shaders with your own. You can use shader modifiers to, for example:
Parametrically deform the surface of a geometry
Simulate realistic surfaces with complex material properties
Add artistic lighting effects such as cartoon-style shading
Create special effects by post-processing pixels after SceneKit’s shading is complete

A shader modifier is a snippet of source code in the Metal shader language or OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) that SceneKit injects into its own shader programs at a defined entry point. Because your shader modifiers are additions to SceneKit’s shader program, using shader modifiers leaves SceneKit’s rendering system intact. That is, you can still use material properties, lighting models, and camera effects to affect the rendered image.
You attach a snippet to a
or
object using its

property, associating it with an entry point corresponding to the stage of SceneKit’s shader program that it modifies: geometry, surface, lighting, or fragment. Each entry point defines a context for the associated snippet, with input variables providing SceneKit’s rendering parameters in that stage and output variables that the snippet writes its results to.
For definitions of each entry point and its inputs and outputs, see
. SceneKit inserts your shader modifiers into its shader program a specific order:
You can use the structures defined by earlier entry points in later entry points. For example, a snippet associated with the
entry point can read from the
structure defined by the
entry point.
The code you provide for a shader modifier must be organized in a specific structure, as illustrated in the example below:

code: // For Metal, a pragma directive and one custom variable on each line:
// For OpenGL, a separate uniform declaration for each custom variable
vec2 sincos(float t) { return vec2(sin(t), cos(t)); }

inlineContent.text: Custom variables declarations.

You can provide your own inputs to a shader modifier by declaring custom variables. Because the syntax differs between Metal and OpenGL shaders, you must include both declarations for your shader modifier to be usable with both rendering technologies. To pass values into custom variables at render time, see
Custom global functions.
If your shader modifier benefits from factoring common code into functions, place their definitions here. If you include custom functions in your snippet, you must place the
directive between your function definitions and the main body of the snippet.
Pragma directives.
As noted above, the
directive separates custom function definitions from the main body of the snippet. If the snippet contains no function definitions, you may omit this directive.

By default, SceneKit automatically uses material properties to determine whether an object should be rendered with partial transparency and uses this information to optimize rendering performance. Use the
or
directive to override SceneKit’s setting.
Code Snippet.
Place the main body of your shader modifier code at the end of the code snippet.

One shader modifier snippet affects both Metal and OpenGL (or OpenGL ES) rendering—SceneKit automatically translates GLSL syntax to Metal shader syntax before inserting your code snippet into its own shader program. (For some simple shader modifiers, SceneKit can insert the same code snippet into either shader language without translation.)

content.text: Providing Custom Inputs to a Shader Modifier

inlineContent.text: You can also declare custom uniform variables in your shader modifier snippet. You provide values for custom uniform variables using
. For each uniform variable you declare in a shader modifier attached to an
or

object, SceneKit observes a key with the same name on that object. When you set a new value, SceneKit automatically binds that value to the corresponding uniform location in the shader program. If you animate a change to the value implicitly (with the
class) or explicitly (with the

protocol), SceneKit interpolates intermediate values and binds them to the uniform for each frame of the animation. For example, the following code animates the fading of a material from full color to grayscale:

code: // Set up the shader modifier with a custom uniform.
// Later, animate a change to the uniform.

inlineContent.text: Because SceneKit binds values to shader variables using
, you can provide values in several ways. If you set a value using the
or
method, or set a target value for a keypath animation, the value must be contained in an Objective-C object. For uniforms of scalar types, you can assign an
object as a value. Assigning a uniform of a vector or matrix type requires an
object containing data of the appropriate type. You can also bind textures to texture samplers using
objects.
Alternatively, you can create an
or

subclass for your custom shadable object and declare properties whose names match those of the uniform variables in your shader. When you assign a value to the property, SceneKit automatically binds it to the corresponding uniform in the shader program. In this case, your properties can use primitive or structure types appropriate to the corresponding Metal or GLSL variables.
The table below lists the Objective-C types for each shading language data type:
GLSL data types
Metal data types
Objective-C type
SceneKit declares the following uniform variables containing global rendering parameters:
Identifier
GLSL Type
Description
The current system time (in seconds) since SceneKit started rendering with the shader.
The bounding box of the geometry being rendered, in model space.
is the minimum corner of the bounding box and
is the maximum corner.
The transform matrices used for converting vertex positions and normals between model, world, view, and clip coordinate spaces.
For detailed definitions, see Rendering Transform Keys.
The inverse matrices corresponding to each transform.
or
The texture contents of the corresponding material property. Declared only if the material property’s
object provides a texture image.
The GLSL type of the uniform variable depends on whether the contents are a 2D image or cube map.
For details on materials, see
Shader modifiers may contain any legal Metal shader or GLSL code, with the exception that SceneKit reserves for its own use all identifier names with the
, and
prefixes.

abstract.text: The standard transform matrix used throughout Core Animation.
The basic type for floating-point scalar values in Core Graphics and related frameworks.
A structure that contains a point in a two-dimensional coordinate system.
An object wrapper for primitive scalar numeric values.
A simple container for a single C or Objective-C data item.
Describes an integer.
Sets the property of the receiver specified by a given key to a given value.
Sets the value for the property identified by a given key path to a given value.
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
The signature for a block called for binding or unbinding a GLSL symbol in a custom program.
A six-sided polyhedron geometry whose faces are all rectangles, optionally with rounded edges and corners.
An object that manages a Metal buffer used by a custom shader program.
A right circular cylinder geometry whose ends are capped with hemispheres.
A right circular cone or frustum geometry.
A right circular cylinder geometry.
A plane that can optionally display a reflection of the scene above it.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.
The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.
Methods you can implement to use your own custom Metal or OpenGL drawing code to render content for a node.
A rectangular, one-sided plane geometry of specified width and height.
A complete Metal or OpenGL shader program that replaces SceneKit’s rendering of a geometry or material.
A right rectangular pyramid geometry.
Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.

abstract.text: Specifies a block to be called before rendering with programs with the specified GLSL uniform variable or attribute name.
Specifies a block to be called after rendering with programs with the specified GLSL uniform variable or attribute name.
A program used when rendering the object.
A dictionary of GLSL source code snippets for customizing the shader programs provided by SceneKit.
Keys for the
dictionary, each corresponding to an entry point in SceneKit’s shader programs where you can attach a custom GPU shader code snippet.
Use this entry point to change the color of a fragment after all other shading has been performed.
Use this entry point to deform a geometry’s surface or alter its vertex attributes.
Use this entry point to provide a custom lighting equation.
Use this entry point to modify the surface properties of a material before lighting is computed.
A geometry based on a two-dimensional path, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
A sphere (or ball or globe) geometry.
A specification for augmenting or postprocessing SceneKit’s rendering of a scene using additional drawing passes with custom Metal or OpenGL shaders.
The common interface for SceneKit objects that support multipass rendering using
objects.
A geometry based on a string of text, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
A torus, or ring-shaped geometry.
A mechanism for creating implicit animations and combining scene graph changes into atomic updates.
A tube or pipe geometry—a right circular cylinder with a circular hole along its central axis.
A representation of a three-component vector.
A representation of a four-component vector.
Create visual effects in a scene by defining a rendering technique with custom symbols.
